channel.title: math on Nacho Dev Blog!
channel.description: Recent content in math on Nacho Dev Blog!

item.title: TEPREL-1B
item.description: TEPREL-1B is a liquid bi-propellant rocket engine developed by PLD Space, a Spanish company working towards a slot in the micro satellite launchers. This engine will be used in MIURA-1 a suborbital vehicle that will be able to carry a 100kg payload to 153km and also serve as a test bed for several technologies. The availiable specs of the engine are as follows: Propellants: Liquid oxigen (LOX) & Rocket grade kerosne (RP1) Engine cycle: Pressure-fed (helium as pressurant) Thrust (sea level): 30kN Burn time: 122 seconds On top of this, we also know that the vehicle carries 1000l of LOX and 600l of RP1 [1][2]

item.title: Rocket nozzle equations - Throat area
item.description: As a rocketry enthusiast, I find it fascinating how rocket engine nozzles work. A while back, I got my hands on a copy of Rocket Propulsion Elements, an in-depth technical book that goes over the ins and outs of rocket propulsion! Chapter 3 focuses on how a nozzle converts the high-pressure low-velocity combustion gases, into a low-pressure fast stream of gas. The fast stream of gases leaving the nozzle is what generates thrust, according to Newton's third law: for every acting force, there is an opposite force of equal magnitude acting in the opposite direction.

item.title: Ray-Cylinder intersection
item.description: For a given cylinder with radius $R$ and height $H$, a ray with origin $P$ and direction $RD$, find the first intersection point $P'$ between the ray and the cylinder. First, I will simplify the problem by flatening the ray (so effectively this becomes a 2D problem). You can understand this as trying to figure out the intersection point between the ray and a slice of the cylinder. $C$ is the slice center: $(Cylinder_x, P_y, Cylinder_z)$
